alert.note: Alert for Clinton; Essex; Franklin; St. Lawrence (New York) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.senderName: NWS Burlington (Northern Vermont and New York)
info.headline: Hydrologic Outlook issued February 16 at 12:00PM EST by NWS Burlington
info.description: ...Winter/Spring Flood Potential Outlook... This is the fourth flood outlook for the 2023 winter/spring flood season. Flood outlooks are issued bi-weekly by the National Weather Service in Burlington, Vermont to summarize the flood potential due to snowmelt and break up/formation of river ice across central and northern Vermont and northern New York. This outlook is valid for the two week period of February 16 to March 2, 2023. ...Overview... The potential for open water flooding is below normal for all of Vermont and northern New York. Likewise, with little ice cover on most area rivers away from the far north, the threat of flooding from ice jams is below normal across most of the area. The only areas where the threat of ice jam flooding is near normal is across northeastern New York and northwestern Vermont where ice cover is slightly greater. Here, a few ice jams are in place and some modest ice movement will be possible over the next few days. The first two weeks in February have been relatively quiet weatherwise, despite a few winter events. Precipitation, and snowfall, on average have been below normal for most of the area. Despite a brief, intense outbreak of arctic air on the 3rd and 4th of the month, temperatures have averaged well above normal. ..Snow Depths and Water Equivalent... Given the trend of milder than normal temperatures for most of the winter, snow depths, not surprisingly, continue to average below normal for nearly all the area. Only a small portion of the northeastern Adirondacks is showing a near normal snowpack for mid-February per data from the National Operational Hydrologic Remote Sensing Center. Depths in general range from bare ground to perhaps 4 inches in sheltered locations of the Champlain and St. Lawrence Valleys. In the lower elevations of eastern Vermont depths range from 4 to 10 inches. Across the mid-terrain of the Green and Adirondack Mountains (1000-2500 ft elev), surveys conducted by NWS Burlington and other cooperative partners showed depths ranging from one to two feet with some variability. Henderson Lake in the High Peaks region of the Adirondacks (1912 ft) had a depth of 18 inches on February 14. Higher summits, mainly above 3000 feet show values from 1.5 to 3+ feet, again with some variability. For example, the Mt. Mansfield snow measurement site showed a depth of 45 inches on February 14. This was only 75% of normal for the date. Not surprisingly, snow water equivalents, or SWE, show similar trends to snow depth values and on average are running below normal for most of the region. In the lower elevations of the St. Lawrence and Champlain Valleys, values average from near zero in areas of near bare ground or patchy snow, to perhaps an inch in favored, sheltered locations. In the lower elevations of eastern Vermont SWE values range from 0.5 to 1.5 inches with some variability. In the mid terrain (1000-2500 ft) of the Green and Adirondack Mountains, 2 to 4 inches of SWE resides in the pack. Some variability exists in this elevation band, but in general these values appear reasonable. NWS Burlington surveys conducted on February 13 showed a SWE value of 4.1 inches at Roxbury Gap in the central Green Mountains (2375 ft elev). At the higher summits, mainly above 3000 feet, values increase to 4 to 6+ inches, though given the limited geographical area of these regions, the ultimate contribution to the spring melt is always more limited. ...River and River Ice Conditions... River flows across the area, where reliable data is present, remain above to much above the climatological normal values for the middle of February. This is indicative of the persistent warmth this winter, as well as a few precipitation events, allowing for runoff and some modest snowmelt. For example, Lake Memphremagog at Newport, VT was about 1 foot above its normal February pool level. Given the above, river ice coverage understandably remains below normal for much of the region, especially across watersheds in central and south central Vermont. Indeed, many of these waterways remain nearly ice free or have largely open channels as of this writing. The Winooski River is one example, showing a mainly open channel from Essex upstream to Montpelier. On far northern streams and rivers, ice coverage is somewhat greater, indicative of slightly colder temperatures over time. The highest ice cover exists on stretches of the Missisquoi, Great Chazy, Ausable and though there has been a bit of ice growth over the past couple of days due to colder temperatures. Far northern rivers, such as the Missisquoi, Great Chazy, Raquette and St. Regis have more extensive ice coverage, but it likely remains below normal in strength and thickness that what would be typical for early February. That said, two ice jams did form over the weekend of February 11, one on the Great Chazy River near Perry Mills, NY, and another on the Ausable River at Au Sable Forks, NY. While no significant flooding was observed near these jams, they will be monitored going forward over the next few days, or until they weaken/break up. ...Soil Moisture and Groundwater Conditions... As mentioned above, the first half of February has been on the drier side across much of Vermont and northern New York. This comes after abundant precipitation during the month of January 2023. The net result has been a decrease in near surface soil moisture over the past two weeks. Near surface soil moisture anomaly maps from February 14 show most of the region in a near normal depiction. Taking a look at groundwater monitoring wells across the region courtesy of the United States Geological Survey ( USGS ), any short term dryness has not been felt in groundwater levels. There are no organized areas across northern New York or Vermont where groundwater is below normal. In fact, levels are near to above normal across most of the region. Some of the highest groundwater levels are seen across northern portions of New York. For example, the groundwater monitoring well at Brasher Falls was at record high February levels with a period of record going back 68 years. ...Weather Outlook... In the near term, guidance suggests generally mild weather by February standards will persist into early next week with some mixed precipitation likely through Friday the 17th. By the middle and latter portions of next week information suggests a gradual cool down back toward more typical late February norms. In terms of climate guidance, The North Atlantic Oscillation (NAO) Index has been positive for virtually all of January and early February. With a positive NAO there tends to be a very fast zonal flow across the northern United States and southern Canada. Any cold air in Canada is quickly shunted east into the North Atlantic Ocean in the fast zonal flow. So Arctic intrusions, although not impossible, tend to be short lived and quickly moderate. This is exactly the scenario we saw earlier this month. Record setting cold in New England was quickly replaced with much above normal temperatures in roughly a 48-hour period. There are some signs that the NAO may weaken or perhaps try and turn negative as we near the end of February or early March. If this happens, temperatures would likely trend more seasonal. The Pacific North America (PNA) pattern has been neutral to slightly positive so far this February. There are signs that the PNA index will be turning a bit more negative as we head into the end of February. With a negative PNA, upper level high pressure is favored across the southeast United States which typically results in more of a broad southwest flow across the east coast and warmer than normal temperatures, at least in the southern portions of the forecast area. The combination of a positive NAO and negative PNA is typically not very conducive to snow across much of the area. However, medium range numerical weather forecast models suggest the cold air may become just entrenched enough for mainly wintry precipitation during the last week or so of February. The official Climate Prediction Center (CPC) medium range forecasts seem to agree with this scenario. Temperatures are expected to average above normal from 20 to 24 February 2023 across the entire region. However, that trend flips during the last week or so of February when temperatures are likely to average below normal. Precipitation is expected to be near to above normal regionwide from now through the end of February. ...Summary... Based on information available at this time, the Winter/Spring Flood Potential Outlook for open water flooding in northern New York and all of central/northern Vermont is below normal over the next two weeks. While river flows, soil moisture, and groundwater levels remain normal to elevated, the extant snowpack and the water contained therein remain below normal. Although the weather pattern is expected to trend more active over the next couple of weeks, no large scale runoff events are foreseen at this time. As a result, this keeps the threat of open water river flooding to a minimum. The threat of flooding due to ice jams is also below normal for most of the area due to a general paucity in river ice coverage and thickness. This is especially true across central and southern Vermont. Where river ice coverage is somewhat greater across northeastern New York and far northwestern Vermont, the threat for ice jam flooding is near to slightly above normal, and mainly through early next week given persistent mild weather. This would include basins such as the Ausable, Great Chazy, Raquette, St. Regis, and Missisquoi. It is important to remember that very heavy rainfall can result in flooding at any time of year, even in areas that have little or no snow on the ground. A graphic depicting the flood potential across the NWS Burlington service area is available online at: www.weather.gov/nerfc/springfloodpotential The next Winter/Spring Flood Potential Outlook will be issued by NWS Burlington on Thursday, March 2, 2023. For access to current weather conditions and forecasts, please visit our web site at www.weather.gov/btv.
